Award.AwardTitle: Utility Based Pricing and Hedging in Incomplete Markets with Stochastic Preferences in a Unifying Framework of Admissibility
Award.AbstractNarration:
The problems of pricing and hedging of financial instruments are of fundamental importance from both theoretical and practical sides of mathematical finance. In this research project, the investigator develops a novel framework and an approach for analysis of various notions of prices and hedging strategies in general models of financial markets. He aims to develop a utility-based pricing method for contingent claims with embedded payment streams.

In a complete financial market every contingent claim can be replicated by a portfolio of the traded securities and therefore admits a unique arbitrage-free price, which is an initial value of the replicating strategy. In an incomplete market, to every contingent claim is associated an interval of arbitrage-free prices (unless the claim is replicable). In order to overcome the issue of non-uniqueness, alternative (equilibrium- or utility-based) approaches have been developed. The present project focuses on the probabilistic process-theoretic aspects of the problems of utility-based pricing and hedging of contingent claims and income streams. The aim of this project is twofold -- investigation of different notions of prices, hedging strategies, and relationships between them, in the settings that include stochastic utility (as a natural generalization of the utility function concept), and a construction of a utility-based pricing methodology for the contingent claims with embedded payment streams, in incomplete continuous-time models of financial markets. A novel concept of a unified framework of admissibility is introduced for the accomplishment of the goals described above. The unified framework permits consideration of the underlying utility maximization problems with different types of budget constraints, in one formulation. On the technical level, the analysis relies on the existing and new techniques drawing on the general theory of semimartingales, stochastic optimal control, and convex analysis. The approach provides a firm ground for an extension of the scope of applicability of the utility-based pricing techniques and for asymptotic expansions of the utility-based prices and hedging strategies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The PI has accomplished all research goals specified in the original proposal (awarded in 2015). The interdisciplinary nature of the proposed work results in contributions to several research areas. Thus, the main accomplishments of the PI's work on the projects related to the core of the proposed work include five published papers and three more under revision. Four out of these eight papers are single-authored. The results can be divided into the following categories. 

1. Advancement of mathematical finance, the PI's primary research area:

a. The unified framework of admissibility is established, and a utility-based pricing and hedging methodology for streams (as opposed to lumps) of income or liabilities is developed. The PI expects this to impact the development of mathematical finance, as the methodology is applicable in very general settings, and it can be used for pricing and hedging of a wide range of securities, streams of income, and also it is suitable for the analysis of so-called dynamically incomplete markets. 

b. An approach for stability and asymptotic analysis of optimal investment problems is developed. The PI expects it to have a long-lasting impact on the stability and asymptotic analysis of related stochastic control problems, backward stochastic differential equations, and some partial differential equations (Hamilton-Jacobi-Bellman equations).

c. The existence and uniqueness results are obtained for a wide range of utility maximization problems in the PI's papers supported by the award. 

2. Contributions to financial economics. A classical problem in financial economics of optimal consumption of multiple goods is formulated in general incomplete semimartingale markets and is solved under minimal model assumptions. In so-called incomplete markets, this problem was open for at least thirty years. 

3. Contributions to stochastic analysis. The main contributions here are in providing more advanced versions of some classical results, such as the Optional Decomposition Theorem and the dual characterization of a certain class of stochastic processes (supermartingales). These results have applications in financial mathematics. However, they are also interesting (and challenging) from the stochastic analytic point of view.

4. Contributions to stochastic control.

a. The existence and uniqueness results are established to some classical problems in stochastic control.

b. The PI has developed a method for stability and asymptotic analysis of optimal control problems that only requires partial concavity (or convexity) of the objective, in one state variable. The method is based on an increase of dimensionality of the value function. Under perturbations of the input data, the method allows one to obtain second-order expansions of the value function, first-order corrections to the optimizers, and to construct controls that match the objective functions up to the second order. This method appears in different formulations in four of the papers published or submitted by the PI.


Apart from the research contributions mentioned above, broader impacts include the following aspects.

The PI supervises a Ph.D. student in his research institution on a research project, "Sensitivity of optimal investment under model perturbations when wealth can be negative," which is closely related to the core of award topic. Such supervision will help in training financial mathematicians of the next generation. At his research institution, the PI has delivered a series of seminar talks aimed at entry-level Ph.D. students, where the PI has discussed the foundations of the optimal investment problem, some methods that were used for its analysis, and some results on asymptotics. The PI has also developed and taught courses on both foundations and advanced topics in financial mathematics. The primary goal was engaging students in the research projects that are closely related to the core of the awarded project.


For the dissemination of results, Since the PI received the NSF award, he gave thirty five presentations (both domestically and internationally) on the subjects of the awarded project. The list of the venues includes top institutions in the US, Canada, Europe, Asia, and Australia. More precisely,  the Henri Poincare Institute, ETH Zurich, Oxford University, Hong Kong Polytechnic University, University of Technology Sydney, University of Toronto, London School of Economics, Imperial College London, University of Minnesota, Carnegie Mellon University, University of Michigan, University of Texas at Austin, Paris Diderot University, University of Alberta, University of Colorado Boulder, Rutgers University, Boston University, Dublin City University, and others. Since 2015, the PI has delivered five colloquia on the projects closely related to the subject of the proposal to a broad audience. The PI has organized sessions on international conferences on the topics related to the core of the awarded project, and the PI spoke at World Congress of the Bachelier Finance Society and SIAM Conference on Financial Mathematics and Engineering, two times at each, about the results supported by the award.
